example.text: What about the 1,550 violent crimes and 9,685 property crimes commit in DC since just January 1st 2023? Will you do anything to protect us from that? [[url]]

That's a starting point for negotiations; Congress can certainly debate the appropriate number of terms. I believe this issue is important because, while there is some value in having years of experience in Congress, it is too easy to become disconnected and entrenched the longer someone serves in Washington.

Here's a quick recap of my work in Congress and here at home over the last year: Co-sponsored 225 bills Lead author of 30 letters to federal agencies and local organizations including letters to: Department of Homeland Security regarding vaccination mandates on H-2A workers and truckers Internal Revenue Service regarding Form 1099-K Changes President Biden regarding anti-life provisions in Fiscal Year 2023 Budget Proposal Major banks regarding paid abortion travel expenses Local officials regarding illegal immigration in SC-5 communities Introduced legislation, most notably: Congressional Term Limits Earmark Elimination Act Putting our First Responders First Act No CORRUPTION Act Fighting Cancer in Children Act Quality of Care for our Veterans Act Accurate and Complete Abortion Data Reporting Religious Freedoms Over Mandates Act No Pay for Congressional Recklessness Act My Congressional offices served over 2,350 constituents in need of assistance with federal agencies such as passports, Veterans Affairs issues, Social Security issues and responded to over 32,760 constituent letters, phone calls, and inquiries. This year the biggest issues I found were the budget and the border.
“Transition Care” Such a quaint term to refer to surgeries, chemicals, hormones, puberty blockers, mastectomies, etc... ON CHILDREN. [[url]]
What about the 1,550 violent crimes and 9,685 property crimes commit in DC since just January 1st 2023? Will you do anything to protect us from that? [[url]]

On a related note, as your representative in Congress, I have many concerns and questions about President Biden's handling of this situation. This is a matter of national security that should receive a high degree of congressional scrutiny in the coming weeks.
Meanwhile, if you have questions about legislation or my votes in Congress, my office in Washington, DC can answer those. You can reach my DC office at (202) 225-5501.
